If you pay any attention to the media-driven vision of the beach, you understand that it's a pristine, beautiful place that we all go to on vacation, and leave no trace of our existence on once we leave.Â 
The Ocean Conservancy has a bit of a wake up call after tallying the results of their International Coastal Cleanup Day: there was six million tons of trash - non in total, but which
The report, released today, 
 of shoreline and collected over 7 million individual items.  The conservancy wants the day pictured as a snapshot of a larger problem, with some 182 pounds of trash being collected every mile of shoreline policed. The charity believes this exposes an attitude of carelessness.:"Trash doesn't fall from the sky, it falls from our hands", said Vikki Spriulli, OC President, in an interview.
Overall, 57 percent of the trash was related to recreational activities, and another 33 percent to smoking. Obviously, this is not an issue that is caused primarily by large corporations, but instead, generated by consumers who can't be bothered to pick up after themselves.
title: Beachgoers Leave 6 Million Tons of Trash
author: whatsrequired
